information_requirement: Is an adversary using steganography to exfiltrate data from or introduce malicious tools to managed mobile devices? (TA0030 - Defense Evasion)

evidence.description: Anomalously large media files are transferred to or from a mobile device over the network, potentially containing hidden data.
evidence.action: Monitor Zeek `files.log` for media file transfers (e.g., `mime_type` of `image/png`, `image/jpeg`, `video/mp4`). For each file, calculate the ratio of bytes transferred (`seen_bytes`) to a typical size for its type and, if available, dimensions. Use statistical methods like the interquartile range (IQR) or z-scores to flag files with anomalously large sizes. Correlate the `uid` from `files.log` with `conn.log` to identify the source/destination IPs and user agent strings. High-risk indicators include large media files from non-standard domains or transfers to known malicious infrastructure.

evidence.description: A mobile application contains known steganographic libraries, or an installed media file on a device has an unusually high entropy score, suggesting embedded data.
data_sources: Mobile Endpoint File System Scan Data
evidence.action: From MDM application inventories, create a list of installed packages. Scan application binaries (`.apk`/`.ipa`) for strings or imported libraries associated with known steganography tools. For on-device media files, periodically run file entropy calculations. Establish a baseline entropy score for various benign media file types (e.g., photos from the device camera). An entropy score significantly deviating from the mean (e.g., >3 standard deviations or approaching the theoretical maximum of 8 for random data) for a given file type is a strong indicator of embedded, likely encrypted, data.
